user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init:
```c
int32 OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init(osal_objtype_t idtype)
{
    int                     ret;
    int32                   return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    pthread_mutexattr_t     mutex_attr;
    OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *impl;

    impl = OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[idtype];
    if (impl == NULL)
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    do
    {
        /*
         * initialize the pthread mutex attribute structure with default values
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /*
         * Allow the mutex to use priority inheritance
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /*
         * Use normal (faster/non-recursive) mutex implementation
         * There should not be any instances of OSAL locking its own table more than once.
         */
        ret = pthread_mutexattr_settype(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_MUTEX_NORMAL);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutexattr_settype failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        ret = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mutex, &mutex_attr);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_mutex_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }

        /* create a condition variable with default attributes.
         * This will be broadcast every time the object table changes */
        ret = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cond, NULL);
        if (ret != 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error: pthread_cond_init failed: %s\n", strerror(ret));
            return_code = OS_ERROR;
            break;
        }
    } while (0);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_Posix_TableMutex_Init:
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mutex;
    pthread_cond_t  cond;
} OS_impl_objtype_lock_t
...
OS_impl_objtype_lock_t *const OS_impl_objtype_lock_table[OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER] = {
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED]   = NULL,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK]     = &OS_global_task_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE]    = &OS_queue_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM] = &OS_count_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM]   = &OS_bin_sem_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX]    = &OS_mutex_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM]   = &OS_stream_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR]      = &OS_dir_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE] = &OS_timebase_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB]   = &OS_timecb_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE]   = &OS_module_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_FILESYS]  = &OS_filesys_table_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE]  = &OS_console_lock,
    [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR]  = &OS_condvar_lock,
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the function and the related symbol definitions for uses of compiler language extensions as would be explicitly documented by a compiler. I did not find any such extensions. Specific features considered and why they are NOT flagged:

- pthread_* types and functions (pthread_mutexattr_t, pthread_mutex_init, pthread_cond_init, etc.): These are POSIX library calls/types, not language/compiler extensions.
- Designated initializers in the OS_impl_objtype_lock_table (e.g. [OS_OBJECT_TYPE_UNDEFINED] = NULL): Array-designated initializers are a standard C feature (since C99), not a compiler extension.
- Variadic macro OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__): Variadic macros using __VA_ARGS__ are standard C (since C99), not a compiler extension.
- do { ... } while (0) idiom: Standard C construct, not an extension.
- typedefs, const-qualified pointer declarations, integer macros (OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR) and the use of strerror(): All are standard C/library usages, not compiler-specific extensions.

Because none of the constructs used in the provided code are compiler-documented language extensions, there are no fragments to report for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
